The Surge of Retail Traders: Even My Dad and Grandma are Traders...


If you follow markets and economics closely, you would have seen some of these along the past few months – millions losing their jobs or getting furloughed, negative GDP growth prints over the second quarter for many economies, small businesses getting hammered by lockdowns and so on. At the same time, there seem to be a huge disconnect between weak fundamentals (growth, earnings etc.) and market rallies from the end of March. Why so?

Central bank intervention, V-shaped (i.e. quick) recovery hopes from COVID-19, high equity risk premium (i.e. earnings yield minus government bond yields) are some of the common reasons put forward by commentators. Another prominent phenomenon that has occurred since lockdowns around the world is the rise of retail traders. Below you see a chart from Goldman Sachs showing daily average trades by retail players on online brokerages in the US (Schwab, Robinhood, IBKR etc.). Imagine yourself being home every day – not going out, no sports betting available, plenty of free time and zero commission brokerages. Boom, there you get retail punters trying to test their luck in markets. This has not only happened in the US, but also in Asian countries including India, Philippines and China. While retail is less impactful in moving markets when compared to large institutional investors like hedge funds and mutual funds, the huge increase in new accounts and increased trading activity could have played a part in fueling the market rally.
